awd_titl_txt: Identifying Opportunities at the Interface of Chemistry and Quantum Information Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded by the Chemistry Division of the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate through the Special Projects mechanism. The principal Investigator is Jeremy Mathis and the co-principal investigator is Kavita Berger, both of the National Academy of Sciences. This work is conducted through the Board on Chemical Sciences and Technology in the Division of Earth and Life Studies. The overall goal is to conduct a consensus study to identify the opportunities and research priorities that exist at the boundaries of chemistry and quantum information science (QIS). The expected outcome is a report with recommendations on how chemistry can move forward and expand the field of QIS while also identifying ways that QIS can impact the field of chemistry. The study is being conducted by a diverse committee with a range of expertise. 

No other studies have been undertaken that have focused so exclusively on the relationship between chemistry and QIS. The study will result in a publicly accessible report that identifies strategic research areas in this complex and highly interdisciplinary area. Key strategies for furthering the fields of both QIS and chemistry are expect to result. Broader impacts of this work could well lead to impactful outcomes such as new drug design and sustainable energy production.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The report Advancing Chemistry and Quantum Information Science was publicly released in June 2023. Since its debut, it has been featured on the National Quantum Initiative website. The study’s committee also briefed congressional staff from the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology (CSST) and the Committee on Education and the Workforce. Key recommendations from the report that addressed new research directions, infrastructure and facility needs, and economic, education and workforce development were discussed.  One week later, CSST held its first full committee hearing on QIS for this Congress, “Advancing American Leadership in Quantum Technology.” These discussions motivated significant amendments and addition to the proposed NQI’s reauthorization bill (as of 12/14/2023) including: 1) authorizing NSF to establish the Quantum Reskilling, Education, And Workforce (QREW) Coordination Hub  to extend new traineeships, fellowships, scholarships, and other workforce-supporting programs to a broader population of STEM students with the potential to enter the quantum field  and 2) authorizing the creation of a new Quantum Instrumentation and Foundry Program to develop devices, hardware, software, and materials, for the use of the quantum industry and research community. Outside of impacting policy, the report has also motivated dialogue and further collaborations among researchers in physics and chemistry, through a series of dissemination presentations at professional society conferences.  

 


Last Modified: 05/30/2024
Modified by: Linda Nhon
por.por_txt_cntn:
The report Advancing Chemistry and Quantum Information Science was publicly released in June 2023. Since its debut, it has been featured on the National Quantum Initiative website. The studys committee also briefed congressional staff from the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology (CSST) and the Committee on Education and the Workforce. Key recommendations from the report that addressed new research directions, infrastructure and facility needs, and economic, education and workforce development were discussed. One week later, CSST held its first full committee hearing on QIS for this Congress, Advancing American Leadership in Quantum Technology. These discussions motivated significant amendments and addition to the proposed NQIs reauthorization bill (as of 12/14/2023) including: 1) authorizing NSF to establish the QuantumReskilling, Education, And Workforce (QREW) Coordination Hub to extend new traineeships, fellowships, scholarships, and other workforce-supporting programs to a broader population of STEM students with the potential to enter the quantum field and 2) authorizing the creation of a new Quantum Instrumentation and Foundry Program to develop devices, hardware, software, and materials, for the use of the quantum industry and research community. Outside of impacting policy, the report has also motivated dialogue and further collaborations among researchers in physics and chemistry, through a series of dissemination presentations at professional society conferences.
